title: Monday, 4th March 2019
bodyHTML:
Manxish Morning each
VV75 morning
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Good morning, welcome, hi, hello, hey there.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
BE11:06am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's etc.

BE11:06am

Internet's weird, right?

Soundbuy Morning
11:06 am

So I was looking for a picture of Ray Kelvin to kick things off. And famously, Mr Kelvin likes to put things in front of his face .....

chad_john Morning. An AIM stock is up 110%, its ticker is "RMP". Made me laugh anyway.

Which is a bit unfortunate given recent events. Makes him look a tad shifty.

MikeB morning

However! About third or fourth on Google image search was for this page .....

BE11:08am

11:08 am

Problem is, that's not Ray Kelvin.

BE11:09am

It's Kelvin McKenzie.

BE11:09am

Which makes the whole page a gigantic libel.

11:09 am

A robot has managed to defame the ex editor of the Sun.

DogDay morning all
BE11:10am

That's your future right there.

undefined

11:10 am

Anyway, we should mark the departure of the actual Ray Kelvin.

VV75 There are no pics of me online, that solves any issues
cheeckychappy I guess if you get accidentally defamed by a robot your quids in?!
Tom Dalgleish Libelled by the failings of the other? Precedents?
BE11:11am

Who's off before the review into Ted Baker's hugging policy even completes.

BE11:12am

Whether this means we'll ever actually see the report, who knows? There's the WPP precedent here.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

However, there's rather less mystery about the allegations.

BE11:13am

Sellside all says, "company should be okay without him".

BE11:13am

Jefferies ........

red @VV75a lot of folks would have an easier life if they did the same
11:13 am
BE11:14am

It is a sad end for Ray’s 32 years building Ted into a global brand. Ray has been an inspirational leader and mentor (in many ways but clearly not all) for many of Ted’s employees as the business has thrived but Ted clearly needs to draw a line under Ray’s behaviour and move forward. Last week Ted announced several negative profit impacts. We hope that the business is now “clean” but we stay Hold.

BE11:14am

Not sure we needed that " (in many ways but clearly not all)" parenthesis.

BE11:14am

David will stay on for c.18 months until no later than 30 November 2020 to support Acting CEO Lindsay Page and team. We believe Lindsay Page and team can ably lead Ted (as they have done in the past) but anticipate that the board will undertake a thorough review and search for potentially new management to lead Ted in its next stage of growth. Meanwhile the independent investigation by lawyers Herbert Smith Freehills (which should conclude in the next couple of months) will focus on company policy, procedures and handling of complaints - in effect we expect a much stronger HR function. Whether Ray will face any potential criminal investigation, or whether Ted will have been found to have signed any NDAs, we do not know.

Ted, under new leadership

Ted will report FY19 results on 21 March and has already profit warned on three factors, saying that FY19E PBT will be £63m (see "A Few More Bumps On The Road"). Hopefully this is sufficient to get Ted back on the front foot. We expect new management (as and when appointed) will look to review the balance of Ted’s stores, concessions and online global operations and also the price competitiveness of the brand given inflating costs. For now, we stay on Hold.

red yes not sure ceo to blame for recent misses here. could be another one dads have shot down, like superdry
11:15 am
BE11:15am

And Liberum.

BE11:15am

The resignation and departure of Ray Kelvin from Ted Baker is unfortunate but understandable. He leaves the business with a strong team. There should be minimal disruption, but we are encouraged that the Board is providing additional support to the executive team. Ted Baker has grown steadily and has become a global brand and we do not see any change to the Group's long term prospects.

BE11:15am

It is disappointing to see a founder leave the business and brand that he founded. However Ray Kelvin leaves Ted Baker with a strong team and culture. The brand has grown steadily from its origins since 1988 and the team at Ted Baker is one of longevity. Ray’s decision to resign will see the business move forward under new leadership but we are encouraged that the Board has acted in a positive manner and will be providing additional support to the executive team.

11:16 am

Pernaffo @BE : Vente Privee (an online store, quite famous, quite large, but based in Europe) closed operations today in the UK. They blame "economic uncertainties". I dont think (but I would be curious to know) they were doing too badly. Is it worth coverage?

11:31 am
BE11:31am

We'll get an appeal, of course, and Canada can indeed be detonated if required. AS we talked about last week.

cheeckychappy @BE - I don't think Branson is that litigious. I think he sees as any publicity is free publicity and therefore good for biz?

Here comes Citi, who've been well in front of this story from the start.

BE11:32am

It is almost certain that this decision will be appealed to the Supreme Court of Canada. We will hear in 6-9 months if the Supreme Court is willing to hear the case; we think it is likely to. If it does, it will probably take another 2-3 years before we hear the final outcome. However, we assume the Supreme Court will uphold the ruling again because of the TDRA and the legal context in Canada.

VV75 Don't they already have money handed over in escrow?
Pernaffo @Pharma: I dont know. I usually come here to get the facts :D
Tom Dalgleish Has big tobacco ever paid out anywhere?
11:32 am
BE11:33am

Only the Canadian subsidiaries are involved in this ruling – The good news is that the parent companies are not involved in the Blais and Létourneau cases. However we think investors should now assume that BAT, PM and JT will no longer be able to access any cash from Canada, even though their Canadian subsidiaries will remain consolidated in their accounts. We estimate Canada accounts for about 4% of BAT’s and JT’s operating profit, and 3% of PM’s. We estimate BAT has about £1B of cash tied up in Canada currently, and PM has about $1B.

Bluesky21 US
Bluesky21 They are still paying the settlement in the US
cheeckychappy @Pernaffo - I'm based in the UK and skint so never spend money on that sort stuff, hence the reason I never heard of...
BE11:33am

But there are more significant cases waiting in the wings – There are other
cases waiting to come to trial in Canada, where the holding companies are being sued in addition to the Canadian subsidiaries, and this makes them much more significant. These are the Provincial Cases, where the provinces are suing for hundreds of billions of dollars to recover healthcare costs. The first, New Brunswick, has a trial that is due to start in November 2019, although it may be delayed (New Brunswick, with a population of 750,000, is seeking up to C$25B-60B in damages).

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian My apologies. The PR decision wasn't his. Nevertheless, it is such a hard job someone has to surfboard with a naked model for business cause.
BE11:34am

We think the lesson from US litigation

11:34 am
BE11:34am

... is that general worries can limit multiples for years, even if the shares do not react to individual cases – US tobacco shares reacted strongly to individual rulings in the U.S. only between 1996 and 1999. However, litigation still effectively capped multiples until 2003, when Engle was decertified.

Pharma Wonder who will be the first out of the traps in Europe when they see the Canadians potentially making $Bns. Better join the queue quickly, or there will be nothing left.
BE11:36am

And Jefferies.

Bluesky21 I suspect BAT bad news is balanced by latest plans from the FDA against vaping sales
Pernaffo @cheeckychappy I hope you dont only invest in things you personally use :D
Bluesky21 Like teenagers won't be allowed into convenience stores that sell e-cigs
BE11:37am

We would expect an additional deposit to be paid
If the tobacco companies do appeal, like last time we would expect an additional deposit to be required. We think, in a worst case, it will be the same amount as the previous appeal. Last time, the court required BAT to pay C$758mn and PMI to pay C$226mn. Both companies were required to pay in 6 equal quarterly installments, starting in Dec 2015. JT was not required to make a deposit but if they were to this time we would estimate, in a worst case, it would be C$145mn.
Unlikely the full amounts are ever settled
If the case was appealed and they lost again, a possible outcome is all 3 names declare bankruptcy. There would be no liability on the parent. Such action would be most likely at BAT, with the fine value way greater than the business value, but we think there is also an argument for bankruptcy at PMI and JT. We estimate Canada is c3% of BAT group profit (annual EBIT of C$500mn), c3% at PMI (C$500mn), and c3% at JT (C$200mn). Bankruptcy could also be sought to force creditor protection such that the government rounds up Quebec and all additional similar cases (Quebec not the only province with such cases) and arrives at a national settlement that can be afforded (similar US MSA payments). What this means is that ultimately, the full amounts are unlikely to ever be paid.

Bluesky21 Otherwise one may worry much more about BAT facing the combination of Juul e-cigs being sold through Altria distribution
11:37 am

BE11:48am

Bottom line… We expect the shares to be soft given (1) ~5% H2’18 EBIT miss, (2)
weaker operating free cash flow, and (3) likely (2-5%) FY’19 cons PBT
downgrades, we think. Synthomer reported H2’18 sales of £785.1m, ~6% ahead of
consensus (£739.4m). However, EBIT for the period was £62.7m, ~5% below cons
(£66.2m), largely a consequence of softer market dynamics in Europe & North
America (destocking, volatile raws), and with the company citing some
transactional headwinds from a softer USD (FY’18 -£10m). H2’18 PBT of £58.9m
was ~3.4% below consensus (£61m). Divisionally ENA was soft down greater than 10% YoY
in the second half (incl. positive portfolio and synergy effects), while ARW was
broadly stable YoY, as Synthomer ramped up its capacity expansion in Q4’18. At
the end of the year, net debt/EBITDA increased to 1.2x (1.1x at the end of 1H’18),
as underlying operating cash flow decreased to £20.0m (from £77.9m in FY17)
with a significant increase in WC (£35m outflow vs £9.5m inflow in FY17),
particularly as raw material prices increased in Q4’18 vs Q4’17 and capex
increased to £75.7m (FY17 £60.3m) mainly due to previously announced capacity
expansions in Malaysia, Germany, US and Italy. DPS of 13.1 was slightly below
cons. expectations (DPS 13.4). We will look to clarify at this morning’s
presentation, the FY’19 guidance which calls for ‘further progress’, versus the
significant step up (+9%) implied in cons. PBT expectations.

11:48 am
undefined
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Most companies can operate on one class of share structure. If Bezos can be decent enough to believe in it, so can others.
BE11:49am

Thanks anonymous reader!

Pharma @1st, yes I do, but making rules that allow allow for tricky edge cases is hard.
BE11:49am

Dear analysts and investors,

We would like to clarify comments made on equity free cash flow during IAG’s results presentation on 28 February.

We expect equity free cash flow to be lower in 2019 than in 2018 based on our guidance of operating profit being similar in 2019 compared to 2018 and on an increase in net capex from €2.2bn in 2018 to €2.6-2.7bn in 2019.

Please refer to our guidance as per RNS Number 4088R on 28 February 2019: at current fuel prices and exchange rates, IAG expects its 2019 operating profit before exceptional items and impacts of IFRS 16 to be in line with €3,230m reported in 2018. Passenger unit revenue is expected to improve at constant currency and non-fuel unit cost is expected to be flat at constant currency. Please also refer to our net capex guidance of €2.6bn in 2019 provided in our Capital Markets Day presentation (slide 171) on 2 November 2018.

We would also like to clarify the impacts of IFRS 16, which we adopt from 2019. The impacts on our balance sheet and income statement are shown on slide 18 of the 2018 results presentation. The impacts on our cash flow statement will be an increase in net cash flow from operating activities, due to the exclusion of operating lease rental costs, which will be offset by an increase in net cash outflows from financing activities due to the inclusion of interest on operating lease liabilities and repayment of operating lease liabilities. We expect the impact of IFRS 16 on equity free cash flow to be negligible.

We plan to provide materials on the impacts of IFRS 16 on our financial statements and key performance indicators in advance of our 1Q19 results.

Regards,

IAG investor relations team

BE11:55am

This was flagged, sort of, a few weeks ago. But it's worth going through the detail.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Here's Citi

BE11:56am

The structure of the deal is relatively complex. “Fully Participating Shareholders”, ie holders of A shares aside from the Rothermere family/affiliates and the employee benefit trust, will receive 0.19933 of an
Euromoney share plus 68.13p in cash per share, and will see a 46.409% reduction in the number of their DMGT A shares held. For the Rothermere family, each A share will receive 25.53p in cash, and it will see a 3.946% reduction in their A shares held. The Rothermere vehicle exists purely to hold DMGT shares and is therefore not participating in the ERM distribution. It is also receiving just £17m cash. Together, according to the company, this equates to 92% less than the value it would be entitled to if it were a “regular” A shareholder [continued] As a result, the Rothermere’s DMGT shareholding is being reduced by
less than the other A shareholders, resulting in an increase in its proportionate interest in the company: the family will now own 36% of the A shares plus ordinary (voting) shares vs 24% pre-the Euromoney distribution (based on owning 30% of the A shares vs 20% previously).

BE11:57am

So anyway, it's probably just a tidy up exercise.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Arguably we think this move is sensible, and is helpful from a “tidying-up” perspective, but is perhaps less impactful for DMGT overall than some of the other options available to it in terms of portfolio rationalisation. After all, it was only a couple of years ago that the market became increasingly focused on a potential sale of the newspaper business – a move that would be significantly more transformational for the group. From a Euromoney perspective, we see this as a very helpful transition: one of the biggest pushbacks we get from investors is around liquidity/free-float and this issue specifically, assuming the transaction is approved, would be largely irrelevant. We rate DMGT Sell (concerns over medium-term growth coupled with rich valuation) and Euromoney Neutral (decent business but ongoing weakness in end-user markets).

Dec69 - Skeptic @GBK, just my view, but appointing someone that's been with the Company 26 years isn't really a dynamic move, more of. Hey lets play is safe
BE11:58am

Though it also gives Euromoney a lot more freedom to make its own way in the world, and there's no reason to think it'll do that alone.

Which may not be to everyone's liking. Here's Merrill.

BE12:00pm

We expect a somewhat muted reaction until the new CEO's intentions for the business are made clear. Investors may be concerned that the appointment does not bring much change, also that highly regarded Andy Briggs may leave.

Tom Dalgleish 1st, all the more reason to bail on thee
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

And here's Barclays.

BE12:01pm

We published a note on Friday the 1st of March (Radical change to unlock value) summarising that we believe radical change would be required from any incumbent CEO to alter the market's view that Aviva was a value trap and we think c£22bn - c£26bn of value can be created for shareholders by disposing of its international businesses and leaving a focused and differentiated UK life and non-life franchise. While initially we do not believe Maurice Tulloch would have been the most likely of these candidates to go down the disposal route, especially since the press release credits him for leading the acquisitions of the RBC GI business in Canada but also Friends First in Ireland. We believe the protracted process of bringing in a new CEO and the rumours of external candidates shows the board's desire to see change within the group and we believe this gives Maurice Tulloch an expanding mandate and will be open to driving value growth at Aviva as the share price has done little over the past 10 years and needs radical changes to cease to be viewed as a value trap.

Furthermore, while we believe some form of kitchen sinking can never be ruled out, we believe the dividend is unlikely to be cut (given Mark Wilson had already restructured the balance sheet) and that some kitchen sinking is already reflected in the price relative to peers.

Pharma @Dec69, if your worst investment was only down 8%, you have not really been trying.
Pi1010 Tulloch has a general insurance background andnot very exiting! Andy Briggs who would have been better will probablly now leave.
BE12:02pm

And it that's all too interesting, here's Goldman.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Overall, we see the appointment of a CEO as a positive for the group, removing uncertainty. Maurice Tulloch has been with the group for 26 years and has been involved in previous group decisions as a member of the senior management team. As a result, investor concerns around major shifts in direction from the group may be allayed by this announcement. Any announcements around dividend guidance and target capital structure, with FY18 results on Thursday (March 7), in addition to clarity around the longer-term strategic direction of the firm, should be taken positively in our view.

BE12:07pm

Despite the healthy results and outlook the shares ended -2% (down c10% at one stage), in our view primarily on concerns on the weakening of Agency membership in H2 (-2%; first YoY decline since 2012). While risks to Rightmove’s model from a disruptive no-deal Brexit are very real (e.g., agency bankruptcies on a transaction shock) we see fears over the progress of this KPI as overdone. We are less concerned around exposure to branch numbers as i) the revenue model is increasingly based upon total contract value as agents change their physical footprints; ii) Rightmove has the pricing power to evolve its revenue model as the customer base develops; and iii) we think the risk of a rapid scaling of dominant hybrid players is receding.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

The company was also upbeat on the long-term opportunity with c50% of agents spending less than 5% of revenue on Rightmove and a key addressable opportunity. Market share of traffic grew in FY18 and ticked up in January, further cementing Rightmove’s no. 1 status in UK property. Reiterate Outperform; increasing EPS, raising TP from 560p to 570p We increase our FY19/20 EPS by c2% on stronger New Homes progress and updated buyback.

BE12:08pm

While Barclays stays on the negative side.

BE12:08pm

Rightmove’s FY results are not totally clean. Yes they delivered a 1% EPS beat, but due to New Home Developments. The no. of UK agents is turning: down 1.5% sequentially in 2H and we think declines could accelerate further with online agent penetration stagnating and end market pressures clear on bricks & mortar. The price increase has gone through for 2019 and they guide to ARPA up in line with expectations (£80 / 8%), but 1) they say there was “more friction” this year, and 2) it is helped marginally by mix. Guidance also implies costs are stepping up at the low end of prior years –all this to just hold margins flat. Taking a step back, this remains a very high quality businessin a tough market, in our view. But growth is slowing -we forecast 7% EBIT growth and 9% EPS growth post buyback this year,and there is no earnings momentum. The stock is expensive on 22x 2020E P/E,in line with the historical avg vs FTSE250 despite markedly slowing growth. We remain UW. Investors looking for a growth play in the UK if Brexit fears abate should gain exposure toAutoTrader (EW) as we see it: it is growing more (low DD EPS), is cheaper (19x P/E), has a business model more tied to end market volumes, and has more levers in adjacent markets to pull long term.
